explanation: The report is correct. Rule 8.13 asks that pointers point to const-qualified types whenever possible. In check_params the parameter is declared as char *const *const argv — the pointed-to characters are not const-qualified, yet the function never modifies the strings; it only examines them (strcmp, sscanf accept const char *). Therefore the deepest pointee type could and should be const (e.g. const char *const *const argv), and the current declaration violates the spirit of MISRA C:2023 Rule 8.13. (Note: changing the parameter to use const may require adjusting call sites if they expect incompatible pointer types, but that is an interoperability/detail consideration — it does not negate the fact that the present declaration fails the “point to const when possible” guideline.)
